CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Three kinds of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) type semiconducting copolymers in which electron donating units of dithienopyrrole ( DTP ) and accepting units of benzothiadiazole ( BT ) were connected with different numbers of thienyl spacers ( x = 0-2 ) were synthesized and used as electron donor materials in polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) combined with fullerene derivatives. The optical band gaps of the polymers could be tuned from 1.41 eV to 1.61 eV by changing the number of thiophene spacers. Electrochemical measurements showed that the increase of band gap is mainly due to the change of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( LUMO ) energy level. The power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of the polymer solar cells based on the three polymers and PC 70 BM reached 3.12% with x = 2 under the illumination of AM 1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 . This approach could provide a simple strategy for designing high - performance D-A type photovoltaic polymers based on the existing polymers and a large potential to improve their performance further. † Electronic supplementary information ( ESI ) available : XRD patterns , DFT and TD - DFT calculations. See Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted much interest due to their great potential to be a renewable energy technology based on simple and low cost manufacture. [1][2][3] The concept of a bulk heterojunction ( BHJ ) utilizing mixtures of a conjugated polymer and a fullerene derivative is regarded as an efficient system for photovoltaic application. 4 The most representative active layers of the blend of regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT ) with fullerene derivatives were extensively investigated. [5][6][7] While the advantage of P3HT is its simple structure with a relatively high hole mobility , the weak point of P3HT as the photovoltaic donor material towards efficient PSCs is the mismatch of its absorption spectrum ( absorption edge is about 650 nm ) with the terrestrial solar spectrum. The band gap of P3HT ( 1.9 eV ) is larger than the optimum band gap range ( 1.3 - 1.5 eV ) for polymer - fullerene BHJ solar cells. 8 Hence , design of photovoltaic polymers with broader absorption toward longer wavelengths , especially in the near - infrared ( NIR ) range , is necessary for high efficiency conjugated polymer donor materials. Thanks to the many attempts that have been made to develop NIR absorbing polymers , a notable improvement of the overall power - conversion efficiency ( PCE ) has been achieved. [9][10][11] One of the most powerful and flexible strategies to design low band gap conjugated polymers involves an alternating sequence of electron - donor ( D ) and electron - acceptor ( A ) moieties along the conjugated polymer main chain.

Let's think step by step.

1. dithienopyrrole (DTP) - electron donating unit
2. benzothiadiazole (BT) - accepting unit
3. thienyl spacers - may not be considered as a "Material Name" entity as it is referring to the number of thiophene spacers (x = 0-2)
4. fullerene derivatives - may not be considered as a "Material Name" entity as it is a general term for a group of materials
5. PC 70 BM - a fullerene derivative, but specified in this context
6. regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) - a photovoltaic donor material
7. NIR absorbing polymers - a group of materials, but mentioned in a general context
8. electron-donor (D) and electron-acceptor (A) moieties - may not be considered as "Material Name" entities as they are referring to the types of moieties and not specific materials.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. dithienopyrrole (DTP)
2. benzothiadiazole (BT)
3. PC 70 BM
4. regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT)
5. NIR absorbing polymers (only if referring to specific materials and not a general group)

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Three kinds of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) type semiconducting copolymers in which electron donating units of dithienopyrrole ( DTP ) and accepting units of benzothiadiazole ( BT ) were connected with different numbers of thienyl spacers ( x = 0-2 ) were synthesized and used as electron donor materials in polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) combined with fullerene derivatives. The optical band gaps of the polymers could be tuned from 1.41 eV to 1.61 eV by changing the number of thiophene spacers. Electrochemical measurements showed that the increase of band gap is mainly due to the change of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( LUMO ) energy level. The power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of the polymer solar cells based on the three polymers and PC 70 BM reached 3.12% with x = 2 under the illumination of AM 1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 . This approach could provide a simple strategy for designing high - performance D-A type photovoltaic polymers based on the existing polymers and a large potential to improve their performance further. † Electronic supplementary information ( ESI ) available : XRD patterns , DFT and TD - DFT calculations. See Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted much interest due to their great potential to be a renewable energy technology based on simple and low cost manufacture. [1][2][3] The concept of a bulk heterojunction ( BHJ ) utilizing mixtures of a conjugated polymer and a fullerene derivative is regarded as an efficient system for photovoltaic application. 4 The most representative active layers of the blend of regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT ) with fullerene derivatives were extensively investigated. [5][6][7] While the advantage of P3HT is its simple structure with a relatively high hole mobility , the weak point of P3HT as the photovoltaic donor material towards efficient PSCs is the mismatch of its absorption spectrum ( absorption edge is about 650 nm ) with the terrestrial solar spectrum. The band gap of P3HT ( 1.9 eV ) is larger than the optimum band gap range ( 1.3 - 1.5 eV ) for polymer - fullerene BHJ solar cells. 8 Hence , design of photovoltaic polymers with broader absorption toward longer wavelengths , especially in the near - infrared ( NIR ) range , is necessary for high efficiency conjugated polymer donor materials. Thanks to the many attempts that have been made to develop NIR absorbing polymers , a notable improvement of the overall power - conversion efficiency ( PCE ) has been achieved. [9][10][11] One of the most powerful and flexible strategies to design low band gap conjugated polymers involves an alternating sequence of electron - donor ( D ) and electron - acceptor ( A ) moieties along the conjugated polymer main chain.

Let's think step by step.

1. Dithienopyrrole (DTP): electron donating unit
2. Benzothiadiazole (BT): accepting unit
3. Thienyl spacers (x = 0-2): number of thiophene spacers connecting DTP and BT
4. Optical band gaps: property that can be tuned from 1.41 eV to 1.61 eV
5. Lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy level: property affected by the increase of band gap
6. Power conversion efficiency (PCE): property of polymer solar cells based on the three polymers and PC 70 BM, reached 3.12%
7. Simple and low cost manufacture: property of polymer solar cells that has attracted much interest
8. Bulk heterojunction (BHJ): concept of a mixture of a conjugated polymer and a fullerene derivative in photovoltaic application
9. Absorption spectrum: property of P3HT with an absorption edge of about 650 nm
10. Hole mobility: property of P3HT
11. Mismatch: property of the absorption spectrum of P3HT with the terrestrial solar spectrum
12. Band gap: property of P3HT, 1.9 eV
13. Optimum band gap range: property for polymer-fullerene BHJ solar cells, 1.3 - 1.5 eV
14. Electron-donor (D) and electron-acceptor (A) moieties: properties of an alternating sequence in low band gap conjugated polymers.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. Optical band gaps
2. Lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy level
3. Power conversion efficiency (PCE)
4. Simple and low cost manufacture
5. Bulk heterojunction (BHJ)
6. Absorption spectrum
7. Hole mobility
8. Band gap
9. Optimum band gap range
10. Electron-donor (D) and electron-acceptor (A) moieties.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| Optical band gaps |
| Lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy level |
| Power conversion efficiency (PCE) |
| Simple and low cost manufacture |
| Bulk heterojunction (BHJ) |
| Absorption spectrum |
| Hole mobility |
| Band gap |
| Optimum band gap range |
| Electron-donor (D) and electron-acceptor (A) moieties |

Paragraph: Three kinds of donor - acceptor ( D-A ) type semiconducting copolymers in which electron donating units of dithienopyrrole ( DTP ) and accepting units of benzothiadiazole ( BT ) were connected with different numbers of thienyl spacers ( x = 0-2 ) were synthesized and used as electron donor materials in polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) combined with fullerene derivatives. The power conversion efficiency ( PCE ) of the polymer solar cells based on the three polymers and PC 70 BM reached 3.12% with x = 2 under the illumination of AM 1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 . This approach could provide a simple strategy for designing high - performance D-A type photovoltaic polymers based on the existing polymers and a large potential to improve their performance further. † Electronic supplementary information ( ESI ) available : XRD patterns , DFT and TD - DFT calculations. Let's think step by step.

1. The optical band gaps of the polymers can be tuned from 1.41 eV to 1.61 eV.
2. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the polymer solar cells based on the three polymers and PC 70 BM reached 3.12%.
3. The band gap of P3HT is 1.9 eV.
4. The absorption edge of P3HT is about 650 nm.
5. The optimum band gap range for polymer-fullerene BHJ solar cells is 1.3 - 1.5 eV.

Note: eV (electronvolt) is a unit of energy, and it is often used to measure the energy of photons or the energy difference between energy levels in atoms and molecules.
